introduction.p: We read the coordinates of points on a scatterplot the same way we do for any other graph.

statement.p:
The scatterplot shows the height and shoe size of a group of men.
State the height and shoe size of the man represented by point A.
Find the heights of two men with the same shoe size.

ol.label: a
ol.li: The man represented by point A has shoe size 11 \frac{1}{2} and is 73 \frac{1}{2} inches tall.
There are two men with shoe size 9, with heights 68 and 73 inches. There are also two men with shoe size 9 \frac{1}{2}, with heights 68 and 71 inches.

sidebyside.p:
The scatterplot shows the heights of dance partners in a ballroom dance class.
How tall is the shortest woman?
What are the heights of the three partners of the 65-inch tall women?

subsection.title: 2. Sketch a line of best fit

introduction.p: Of course, the points on a scatterplot may not lie on a straight line. But if they seem to cluster near a line, we can try to find that line.

statement.p: Sketch a line of best fit for the scatterplot in part 1.

solution.p: We draw a line that lies as close as possible to all of the data points. As a rule of thumb, we try to keep equal numbers of points on each side of the line.

sidebyside.p: Which of the lines fits the scatterplot best?

subsection.title: 3. Fit a line through two points

introduction.p: If we don't know the slope of a line, but we do know two points on the line, we can calculate the slope first and then use the point-slope formula.

statement.p: Find an equation for the line that passes through (2,-1) and (-1,3).

stack.p: We solve this problem in two steps: First, find the slope of the line, and then use the point-slope formula.

statement.p: Find an equation for the line that passes through (-6,-1) and (1,3).

answer.p: Step 2: Use the point-slope formula. y=\dfrac{4}{7}x+\dfrac{17}{7}
